byline.contributor: Milan Schreuer reported from Paris, and Sewell Chan from London. Melissa Eddy contributed reporting from Berlin.
byline.original: By MILAN SCHREUER and SEWELL CHAN

abstract: Eccentric Belgian ban on overnight raids prevented police from entering house where Paris terror attack suspect Salah Abdeslam was reportedly staying; lackluster French and Belgian efforts to capture suspects have frustrated some, while highlighting conflict between security and privacy in terrorism investigations.
lead_paragraph: The authorities said that one of the attackers may have escaped from the police in Brussels because of a law barring raids between 9 p.m. and 5 a.m.

headline.main: Belgium Says Law Limiting Raids May Have Allowed Suspect in Paris Attacks to Escape
headline.print_headline: Belgium Says Law on Raids May Have Allowed Suspect to Escape

snippet: The authorities said that one of the attackers may have escaped from the police in Brussels because of a law barring raids between 9 p.m. and 5 a.m.
